text: all right we're gonna get started now so the next session in the spotlight track is black sky advancing the geospatial
revolution with a cloud first approach and we're gonna do a you know a speech
and then when you do the Q&A I'd ask if you could queue behind the microphones
this time it's just a little bit easier for us for logistics also I'd like to remind everyone do feedback in the app
so my pleasure to introduce Robert Kahn the director of software engineering for
Space Operations and Scott Herman the vice president of black sky product
development thank you both so good
afternoon everybody thanks for joining us we're going to talk a little bit about black sky and spaceflight
industries some of the projects that we're working on in particular how we use Amazon Web Services is really the
critical infrastructure that we build our mission requirements are functional services our customer facing interface
is on top of we'll talk a little bit about the type of missions that were using Amazon for will go into a little
bit of the architecture and then we'll do some Q&A at the end really our premise at black sky is that
the world is becoming increasingly instrumented sensor networks are proliferating and they're proliferating
not only in space but in the air on the ground even on and under the sea even
our cellphones our sensors and so we look at the world from the perspective of global monitoring how do we view the
world in terms of emerging crises or threats to the supply chain of a commercial industry or what are our
competitors doing what are they up to and how can I find out about that through the use of remote sensing and
global monitoring type of products the way we do that is through a collection
of kind of four different systems or processes or functional areas the first
of those is what we call our global collection network and this is really how do we tap in so the proliferating
sensor networks that are rising around the world not only what's happening in terms of small
SATs what's happening in terms of the rise of the drones what's happening in industrial IOT and again even things
like cell phones as sensors how do we bring that in when we bring all the data in we're now trying to figure out what
kind of global activity is happening and what kind of monitoring can we do to provide things like indications and
warning trending of commodities and supply chains what is your extended partner look like
what kind of risk do you have in your operational business flow or obviously from a national security perspective
what are potential bad actors doing and how do we kind of prepare for that the third thing that we're doing is once we
have all this data brought in is we're running a set of analytics against it to provide what you might almost call
hyperlocal insight very very precise geo precision of events that are occurring
around the world along with assessments of magnitudes and risk factors and
scoring to help us figure out what do we need to bring to to people's attention there's a tidal wave of data out there
there's an even greater tidal wave coming as more and more sensor networks proliferate how do we make sense of that
in addition to using lots of existing sensors and emerging sensors that are
out there the fourth component is we're actually building one of our own sensor networks and that's what we call the black sky constellation it's a
constellation of satellites for remote sensing that will provide us premium fuel for our analytics engine that we
can combine with many many other sources of data so that's kind of our premise what this allows us to do is to give our
customers what are what we consider global monitoring services and that can be tasking in collection services being
able to tell satellites or being able to task or pulse sensor networks to get information back about particular issues
whether they be adversaries or competitors or even your own extended supply chain we're doing global
monitoring what is happening in the world and what is emerging as potential threats to your country or to your
business how do we watch for those emerging threats how do we do anticipatory or predictive analytics
against that to kind of forecast what may be happening and then how do we provide meaningful geospatial intelligence reporting
against that that can be used not only by sophisticated kind of national security public sector community
audiences but layman construction foreman a hedge fund analyst a business operator
who's trying to figure out how does my extended supply chain in Europe that you
know how did the flooding impact the factories that I'm dependent upon in
terms of the constellation that we're building in addition to using lots of the satellites and drones and industrial
IOT sensors asset tracking sensors environmental sensors that are out there
we're building our own constellation and the goal is to build up to 60 satellites
put them into a constellation that is really looking at the earth with a
revisit rate of up to 15 minutes every 15 minutes over a particular area so
when we talk about intraday revisit the goal is to be able to get that up into
the anywhere from 12 to 24 times a day revisit over a fixed facility we are not
a mapping program we're really not trying to develop base maps we're not building mosaics we are a point target
collector that is specifically tuned toward facilities so a typical use case
for us with our customers is I have 300 facilities and country X that I want to monitor and I want to understand anytime
there is significant change in those facilities there may be an indicator of activity that I need to pay attention to
so a very different model from a traditional remote sensing or mapping type mission where we're collecting 24/7
we're collecting daytime nighttime we're collecting across multiple phenomenology and we're really trying to zero in on a
set of facilities understand the pattern of life associate associated with those facilities and give indications and
warning based on that so this is a picture of our very first satellite this is back in 2016
we launched a pathfinder satellite a prototype satellite you know learn how to fly test some of the flight
components make sure it's ready to go this is sitting on the pad in southern India this was launched with one of our
partners the Indian Space Agency on what's called a PSLV which is a polar orbiting launch
vehicle and up it goes and you can see our mission patch down there in the corner basically when we talk about
Amazon Web Services how does this mix of sensor networks and analytics and global
monitoring kind of fit together well we are all in on Amazon everything we do
runs on Amazon everything we have is in a Amazon architecture that includes our
big data analytics that includes our user interfaces customer order
fulfillment satellite mission planning constellation management image
processing of the data coming off of the satellites both third party satellites on our own satellites it's all in our
poor IT team has really one job and that's to issue laptops and keep the mail server running everything else is
in Amazon and we'll talk about that in a little bit more detail in just a minute the other thing that we do is we use a
very wide range of Amazon services not just the you know typical s3 and a c2
but literally we use more than 75 different Amazon services if Amazon has
offered a service that does what we need to do we're going to jump on that and make that part of our core architecture
we have kind of a running joke we send a team to reinvent every fall and they come back and go we got 10 more services
we need to add to our architecture so you know it kind of goes to the point that you don't want to reinvent the
wheel there's a lot of things that are constantly being developed as part of the Amazon services infrastructure that
we can leverage we are cloud first we are cloud architected we are not Rijo
stood we are not lifting shift this is really about big data analytics designed to use the scalable elastic
infrastructure that we get by pretty much betting it all on Amazon as our core infrastructure provider the other
thing I would mention is that we use a combination of public Amazon Web Services but we also run part of our
architecture and gov cloud and Roberts going to talk a little bit about the reasons we do that and we also have a
presence on c2s if you know what that is so what I'm going to do is I'm going to talk a little bit
about kind of the customer-facing part of the black sky global monitoring offering and then robert's going to come
up and talk a little bit about how we use Amazon in terms of our technical architecture for what's happening behind
the scenes with our constellation how do we run our space systems how do we do our mission planning how do we do our
image processing so basically when we talk about black sky is a set of monitoring services the
conceptual architecture looks something like this on the left hand side we're pulling in data from a wide range of
sensor networks this is high volume high velocity millions of hits per day data
this is a big data problem this is a streaming data problem this is a near real-time data problem and it spans
space and air and ground and water and cellphones and anything you can kind of
put together if we can find it as a data source we're gonna try to figure out how to bring it in and exploit that data to
get a better understanding of the kind of things that are happening on the earth that could impact your organizational entity along the bottom
one of the things that's really important for us is places facilities what are my 300 facilities worldwide and
how do I monitor what's going on what are the threats to my facilities what are my competitors facilities or my
adversaries facilities what is my extended supply chain who am i dependent upon upstream and downstream in my
business operations and what's going on with them that I may you know want to have an understanding of and then the
output from all of this is a series of lightweight web interfaces mobile
interfaces data streams and api's that can push this data into other systems we
do not want to be yet another stovepipe in a certainly in a public sector agency what we want to do is feed these
high-value refined events and alerts into the systems of record that you may
already be dealing with so the API is and outbound data feeds and alerts are a very big part of what we're putting
together so here's an example this is a screen that's basically showing a
density of observation that's the heat map so millions of observations per day and we're kind of showing where is the
intensity of those observations but the icons are the events that the system is
boring and thresh holding providing better joo precision and accuracy - and saying hey analyst hey operator hey
business leader you need to pay attention to this this is happening in the proximity of a place that you care about so i'll give you a couple examples
of that we basically take the world's data and we try to sort and organize it
in near-real-time in two different thematic what we call channels so it's almost like you get the sports package
and inside of it you can watch football or hockey right so we kind of do the same thing we say we have a whole
collection of events related to crime or geopolitical conflict or environmental
danger humanitarian refugee new construction and particularly around
industries like energy or oil and gas within those channel topics you can
select the programming that you care about so maybe I care about geopolitical conflict as a channel but what I want to
focus on is the Turkish incursion into the Afrin area of Syria and I can tune that dial down and have that as a very
specific feed of information flowing to me across all of these different data sources so as an example this is a one
of our dashboards it's almost a Netflix type thing where you can flow around it you see these things streaming in you
can hover over them it'll tell you kind of what's going on you can see some of the things I've been interested in lately the Qatar blockade refugee issues
and Myanmar earthquake warnings coming from seismic networks we had mentioned
the incursion by Turkey and the Syria what's happening in terms of Iranian protest these are all things that isin
end-user can tune and share within my organization based on these higher level topics like crime refugee geopolitical
conflict and natural disaster here's an example where I've drilled into one of those and again all hosted in Amazon
I'll talk about the architecture behind this in just a minute but you can see some of the scoring what is our confidence around this particular event
what's the geolocation accuracy what are the sources that we use a particular event may have come from literally
hundreds of sources across different phenomenology you know it may be social
media may be news and may be satellite imagery it may be industrial IOT data it may be scientific instrumentation data
all those different things can feed into these common aggregated topics and channels here's an example where we're
actually looking at industrial IOT data across an extended supply chain and this is actually Mitsui which is a Japanese
heavy industry conglomerate and their iron ore commodity supply chain where it
starts with the mines in Australia Western Australia we're tracking the heavy mover dump truck equipment we're
tracking it as it gets on the trains and is loaded onto these giant mile-long ore trains we track every train as it's
moving around we track the the ore as it flows into the ports in northern Australia we track backups into the
ports congestion what are the impacts to the ports from things like labor unrest or cyclones that's been a big thing this
year and then we track the ships themselves across all of the different coups all the different company entities
and where are their destinations where are they going what's the tonnage what's the throughput and that gives us
some really interesting things we can do around commodity trading and the one chart that you see in the lower right
that is actually a showing a series of two to three week leading indicators where by watching what was happening in
the ports and in the the mechanics of the supply chain trucks trains you know
mining equipment we were able to get two to three week leading indicators against the coal and iron ore indices coming out
of Australia and if you're a hedge fund that's really important anomalies make money predictions make money and that's
very much what we're focused on here's another example we've been tracking some Chinese oil
smuggling this isn't a oil transshipment port near Singapore in this case what
we've done is we've said we want to go out and pulse the network of news and social media and figure out what are the
investment issues and the ownership issues around this particular facility so we've gone out and canvassed and and
brought this data back put it through a pipeline of natural language processing I'll go into that in just a little bit
all running on Amazon of course to give me some sense of what's happening around this area that might give me some clues
as to what's going on and then I'm going to switch gears completely I'm going to say well I also want to understand imagery over this facility so tell me
all the imagery that's available recently for this area and so you can see we're pulling back imagery from a
wide variety of providers some of these providers maybe people you already work with as well as some you may not have
heard of and we're pulling back electro-optical imagery or SAR imagery or RF collection there's a lot of
different phenomenology we can bring to bear but it almost becomes an amazon.com like e-commerce interface to be able to
get at geospatial data over facilities that you care about here's another
example this is Africa this is every image collected in the last 12 months that has 20% or better cloud cover from
a quality perspective and then each color that you're seeing there for each of the polygons on the map represents a
different satellite system that's providing the imagery in that area so for example the light blue kind of aqua
color is Airbus platies you can see there's some dense concentrations over the middle-east and over the former
French colonies of western Africa no surprise there so let me talk about
Amazon Web Services in particular now this is a dense chart and I'm not going to go into every little block but
there's several key takeaways I want you to get from this chart number one is every component that you see is running
in Amazon Web Services we run a micro services architecture we
use immutable containers docker containers to do provisioning we do
continuous integration continuous deployment across this this collection of servers it's all auto scaled so that
as we get demand from inbound data or we get demand from users on the on the you know the the demand side everything can
scale up and down our pilot light mode pilot light is the smallest configuration is about 70 servers
running continuously processing all these millions of observations that come in organizing them into these event
streams and then pushing out the alerts and notifications across a variety of interfaces scaling up they can literally
scale up to thousands of nodes as we burst against different types of data so
this is really the epitome of elastic computing in terms of auto scale because
of that that means we have to spend a lot of time thinking about cost and that means things like reservists
versus spot instances in the auction and how do we architect our microservices so
that each one is immutable and discreet and serves a particular function but we're not wasting efficiency by having a
whole bunch of services that are sitting idle most of the time chewing up compute cost so if that's something you're
interested in I can do hours on that topic alone but it's very much a factor for us and thinking about how do you run
a complex big data high performance compute architecture within Amazon where
you don't have an unlimited budget this is a cost of goods sold for the revenue
that we generate with our customers so cost is a big factor let me talk a little bit about some of the things on
the chart real quick one of the big takeaways is that we're pulling in all of this data across all these different
phenomenology different data requires different processing requirements
there's not a one-size-fits-all it's not throw it into s3 or throw it into elastic and run queries against it what
we're trying to do in most cases is we're trying to extract entities or determine features or establish
correlation and fusion across these different data sources so the first one you'll see on there is what we call our
narrative pipeline narrative means text processing so that's industry publications it's social media it's
hyper local news we bring in over 40 to 50,000 different hyperlocal news
services across dozens and dozens of languages this is a natural language
processing in LP pipeline and it's primarily based on lambda and Kinesis
running a lot of our algorithms around doing NLP entity extraction geo precision and accuracy so that's one
type of technology stack within the platform another one I want to point out is the tracker pipeline this is for
tracking movers these are things like let's where all the cell phones at where are all the ships at where all the
airplanes at where's the mining equipment you know how long does it take to get from point A to point B when is
there ingress or egress from a particular area of interest a particular boundary condition what's the magnitude
of tracts within a particular area like a port what's the linger or loiter time the
hang time of things that are moving in and out of a particular facility that's all mapped into our tracker
pipeline that's running on Amazon using technologies like spark and parquet and
again I can talk to you offline if you want to learn more about that the final one I wanted to touch base on is the way
we do some of our image processing and what we're doing for image processing is we are doing pattern recognition through
machine learning and computer vision and we're doing this not only for satellite imagery we're also doing this for the
photos that can be harvest from places like news and social media so find me every image every iPhone image that has
a crowd in it or a fire in it or a flag in it or one of our favorite says find
me camouflage right any social media image that has camouflage in it might be
interesting it could be a fashion statement it could be something a little more interesting and we'll find out one of
the interesting anecdotes I'll talk about before I turn over to Robert in this this pattern recognition image
processing chain where we're doing entity extraction feature extraction and pattern recognition and by the way
that's a tensor flow based architecture that we've made some heavy refinements to we were looking for tanks in Eastern
Europe and trying to do very very broad surveys not only from overhead imagery but from social media news media around
when two tanks show up well like in the United States every small town has a statue of like a Confederate soldier or
a Union soldier in Eastern Europe every small town has a t-34 tank from World War two on a pedestal and every one of
those shows up as a legitimate hit on armor in our pattern recognition so we
had to tune and figure out how do we more precisely exclude certain types as
well as not you know losing legitimate pictures of armor within those those
those images so as an example of the kind of work that's happening that pipeline across all those pipelines we
generate a set of events those events are categorized fused across phenomenology and then if they meet
certain alert conditions they're thrown out to operators analysts users to say hey you need to pay attention to this so
that's kind of the idea that's going on here again all based on a fairly large menagerie
not only Amazon based services but some of the the new cutting-edge technologies
that are being used for things like big data processing natural language processing image processing etc so with

isn't just finance and accounting it's running a satellite network and dealing with the ground control Robert hi there
so again my name is Robert Kahn I am director of software engineering for
Space Operations at Space Flight industries of which black sky is apart that means I am responsible for the
software that runs on the satellite itself doing things like command and sequencing radio communications and also
attitude determination and control so we can actually point at a particular target I'm also responsible for software
that runs in the ground stations themselves ground stations have amazing
number of components in them and we have to do things like set up the radios sequence the in-control antennas so that
they point at the satellite while it goes by and then when everything is done where we've pulled everything down for the satellite relay it all the way back
to the to Amazon where we control and the system and make decisions on what to
do next and one interesting thing about that is that as a US company controlling a satellite network requires that you
issue commands from the location on the US soil and Amazon gov cloud really
helps us out in that what that case so what you see here is a picture of what
our constellation will look like on the left you see the orbits that would be
going around the earth some of them are in Sun synchronous orbit and some of them are inclined orbits so that they go over populated areas more and then again
on the right there is the first two satellites that we launched called the Pathfinder series that we launched them
in 2016 that mission is now over and I'm completely focused on our next generation satellite here's the picture
that was taken by the Pathfinder light of North Korea on an airport that
was just built all the pictures that we took of that never showed an airplane on the runways itself but it gives you an
example of what we were able to do just with the Pathfinder satellite which was again just experimental so now I'm going
to talk a little bit about how the concept of operations and our ground stations so this one is kind of a bit of
eye candy here but if you look in the lower right you can see a customer's making a decision to order something so
it's or task through Scotts platform and then we have to send that to our
centralized system where it will say which satellites are available and then with something we call mission planner
will determine which satellites will take pictures and when and then we have to send them out to the ground stations
where they will be the instructions will be uploaded to the satellite satellite will collect the picture and then it
will download it at the next available ground station where we have chosen which picture will be downloaded first
so that it can be delivered to the customer there that has the most need the fastest once it gets back down to
the ground then we send it through an image processing pipeline to generate the nice picture you run it through some
quality checks we don't like the quality check we'll retask it and take the picture again if we do like it then we
give it off to Scotts system and he takes it from there so what this shows
is an example of two of our ground stations and the upper left there is our ground station in Fairbanks that's a 7
meter x-band dish and s-band dish that we use to do high-speed communications of the satellite and then one in the
lower right is our one in Invercargill New Zealand you can notice that we have one very far north one very far south
and some of them in the middle are ideal for what I called those inclined orbits but when you're doing sun-synchronous
orbit the farther north you are the farther south you are is best so now
what this shows is there's a lot of detail on this slide so I'll try to go through this this is the satellite
operations architecture and on the very top there is the platform operations and business systems that Scott has and then
we get down to the next layer where my work starts and that's the ground and control software as well as imaging
so again in grounding control software when we get orders in from the platform saying take pictures here or there then
we give it to the mission management system it makes a decision what to do and sends it off but it also then relays
everything to the ground station where the radio chain will then upload it to the system and then we will exchange
information with a satellite bringing down a bunch of telemetry and then we will send that telemetry back to our
system to say is the satellite running correctly where all the pictures taken did everything work right and go from
there when you look at the ground station Hardware on kind of in the middle left
in the green there that shows that we do UHF communications X and s band
communications for high-speed communication and then there there's a server on there that orchestrates
everything together so there's a set of many moving parts in a ground station and our software controls all of that
and then on the space side you can see in the blue is attitude determination
and control command and data handling which I called command and sequencing we also do telemetry and monitoring so if
something goes wrong with the satellite it will put itself and do a safe State and relay that information to us and
then we have it what's called the electrical power system and one of the things you have to do when you develop satellite software is you have to
control every single aspect of what it does and so we have to turn everything off when we're getting ready to do radio
communications we have to turn on the radios we're getting ready to turn it on take a picture we have to turn on our
pelos interface card turn on the camera point everything at the ground and start taking pictures and then when you look
in the one it's in purple that's kind of more of a the hardware aspect of it and there's again as almost as many parts in
the satellite is there in the ground station and the flight software controls all of that so but you guys are here to
hear about AWS not at the insides of my satellite and so our black sky satellite system was designed for AWS from the
beginning we do all of our space operations on AWS and we use AWS for
multiple environments which I'll go into some more detail and then one thing that's been really helpful for end
and development is using at the AWS for satellite and ground station simulations we also do automated automated
provisioning of our environments we use VPC networks to control connect to all
of our ground stations back to our central services and then we love to use hosted services such as elastic search
or RDS for databases or sqs for sending messages from one system to another
saying hey it's pictures arrived start processing them and then I'll talk a little bit about consequences of
designing for AWS because it's in the satellite business it's not consequence-free and a little bit about our future goals
so our system was designed from scratch for AWS we designed this system for
lights-out operation we have a room that we call the Mission Operations Center and when we were doing early what they
call launch in early operations of the satellite a whole bunch people climb into that room we do a whole bunch of stuff it's very small it gets hot don't
like spending time in there so we want it to be all lights-out we also designed with security in mind so we do not use
fortress security there's many different ways that you would have to penetrate our system to be able to get to control
of a satellite which and probably would mean breaking into gov cloud which i think is a pretty tough thing all of our
systems run Python on Linux in docker containers distributed on managed ec2
instances and I'll talk a little bit about that but a really important thing for satellite operations is that gov
cloud provides ITAR and ei our compliance as I said when you command a satellite whether it's in our mission
operation center or automated systems running in gov cloud they must be located on you on US soil and go cloud
gives us all of that we have a direct connect from our Mission Operations Center to the gov cloud which allows us
to securely command and satellite operations but the thing that I would like the best because I'm a software engineer and I like to build things is
that we used physical and mock satellites and ground stations to test the system from the very beginning and
also develop the flight software and the nice thing about that is that when we had problems with say
with the encryption between the satellite and the ground we're able to resolve it end to end without having to
say oh we got into space and we can't talk to our satellite because the key isn't working which would be absolutely devastating so I'll give you some
examples of the things that we do on AWS we do mission planning so we are building a multi satellite system we
decide which satellite is going to take which picture by looking at the entire system holistically we have people who
are experts in what's right we're for
determining where the satellite is going to be all of the things that are related to that and then that's the bills our
aerospace engineers and they developed a mission planning system which then tells constellation management this is what I
want to do constellation management will then tell the ground stations hey here's the new instructions for satellite X
upload that download these pictures relay them back in this order so that they can be processed we have something
called a mission script builder which runs which will create take the commands that were generated by mission planning
and constellation management securely encrypt them and send them out to the ground station because you cannot make
decisions on which command to generate at the ground because it's likely that the ground is not located in the US and
so we have to send that all encrypted so that nobody can break into it and figure out what's going on we have something
called the satellite model which keeps track of all the satellites we have a tasking interface which Scott's systems
will use to say hey take a picture of this and then we also have something called an ephemeris service we'll tell
you where the satellites are right now and in the future so that when Scott's customers are saying hey I want to take
a picture that system can say hey you this your next opportunity is take it is in four hours when the satellite will go
over your target and then we also have something that's related to that is the image feasibility service and then we do
all telemetry and monitoring on the ground so every time we connect to a satellite we get a stream of historical
and real-time telemetry and we make instance decisions on what to do with that all the stuff that's on the right
there is very specific and very esoteric to Space Operations so if you have
questions about that you can ask me after the presentation
again this is my favorite slide because I like building satellites I like operating them but building them is the
best and if we look at the bottom slide there what you see on the left is what the satellite how the satellite is
emulated on an Amazon ec2 instance and then we have an emulated ground system
right next to it and in the very back is the constellation management which is running in the cloud the nice thing
about all of this is that we are able to define new environments on demand so an
example of that would be our development environment this is when we test you know the developers are working on it there's no physical hardware involved
everything's purely virtual and then we say ok now we have a staging system that looks just like production but we want
to test our updates there but we have another environment called ops test because I don't actually get to run the

100 satellites in it including one at some of our own and when we do that we
have to suddenly roll out special environments we don't know they're coming or we just get the launch services says hey we need this now and
we're able to spin that up really quickly now I'm going to move on to AWS
for ground and for satellite and ground station simulation so we designed the
system to run all of the satellites from right from the very beginning and because we can emulate satellites we
just spun up you know hey we need 60 satellites to try this out but that requires the use of certain emulation
environments because satellites are notorious for being very old hardware they're like your Mac from 20 years ago
and so they use power pcs but so we have to run that emulation software but it just runs on a regular a double us Linux
incident running x64 this allows us to test our
system both at scale so all the planning all the constellation management's tested at scale and the nice thing about
it is I can arbitrarily combine real hardware and fake emulated hardware at
the same time so if I want to hook it this system up to a real satellite in one of our test facilities I can do that
but I want to use real ground station equipment I can do that and all the time controlled by either our production
systems or Devon stage systems for controlling at all again now getting
system or the esoteric things so some of the things that we do to be able to manage all of these environments is that
we use tools for automated provisioning what they do is they provision all the
ec2 instances all the s3 storage all the connectivity everything including
secrets management cluster management and providing DNS and configuration
management to the ground system so the ground systems need to know where what to talk to you back in gov cloud because
they're relaying information back and all these automated processes take care of that for us I'll have some feedback on that when I
get to you our future goals one thing that's really good is what we use transit VPC networks this is a
relatively new feature from Amazon as soon as we knew it was available we jumped on it right away because what
this allows us to do is define software firewalls between all the systems and very easily configure them at a very
fine level to connect various things so I can say one part of a ground station can connect to you gov cloud but it
can't connect to anything else or like our corporate systems and then we do use a number of hosted services RDS provides
database services elasticsearch is a system that takes all of our telemetry all the SIS logs that come down from the
satellites and from all of our ground stations all go into elasticsearch and then we can then query that as a way to
generate alerts and notifications to the operators and then a very simple thing is just the sqs which when a allows us
